Quoth ktbarrett:
> I am trying to run more than one JUnit test from Ant which shares 
> some static data through the VM. The following is an excerpt from my 
> Ant script.
  [...]
> The problem is, the VM seems to fork whether I tell it too or not. My 
> first test (SupplierTest) is creating some static objects, and my 
> second test (ConsumerTest) is trying to use those objects. The 
> problem is that either Ant is creating a new VM or a new ClassLoader 
> so my data is not available.
> 
> Any ideas?

First, have you tried the following?
	<target name="test">
		<junit fork="no">
			<test name="SupplierTest"/>
			<test name="ConsumerTest"/>
		</junit>
	</target>

Second, a quick glance through the Ant 1.4.1 source makes me think
Ant doesn't make a new VM if you say fork='no', but it does make
its own ClassLoader regardless.  (Note that the <junit> task
supports a nested <classpath> element, so I imagine this is
necessary.)  I encourage you to study the source for more
information, or to inquire on the Ant mailing list (which I assume
to exist).  And you could always write your own Ant task if the
out-of-the-box behaviour is not what you want.

Third, is it possible your objects are being garbage-collected
between the tests?

Finally, it is usually considered desirable that tests not
interact with one another.  It might be best to either (a) unify
the two tests to use the same test fixture, or (b) to make the
latter test do its own set up so it doesn't depend on the former
being run.  What's the motivation for the inter-test dependency?
